Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Collaborative Research: Social interactions. social connectedness, and health outcomes during the COVID-19 pandemic

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration: Good mental and physical health depend on a strong sense of social connectedness. The restrictions of the COVID-19 pandemic, and the resultant social isolation and loneliness, have caused that connectedness to deteriorate. Despite decades of research, relatively little is known about the characteristics of social interactions that lead to improvements in social connectedness and, ultimately, to improved health. This project seeks to gain better understanding of how social interactions support social connectedness. It examines the effects of the social isolation and psychological distress that result from social distancing and stay-at-home policies. The research considers activities people perform together, the types of people who serve as interaction partners, the emotional tone and the modality of interaction (in person, phone, text, or video). The study uses longitudinal surveys with a nation-wide panel of U.S. adults to assess the ways in which social interactions provide the route through which social ties are maintained, the regulation of relationships occurs, and social support is exchanged. The project will ultimately inform the development of health-related interventions in this and future pandemic situations. <br/><br/>This project seeks to advance theory about how everyday social interactions influence general social connectedness, including loneliness, perceived social support, and strength of social ties. In addition to advancing theory, the research addresses the more immediate need to understand the consequences of social distancing policies. Identifying the most beneficial social interactions can help support just-in-time interventions to improve social connectedness and related public health recommendations. To achieve these goals, the research collects longitudinal survey data over a three-week period in which U.S. adults complete multiple surveys each day to describe the frequency and characteristics of their social interactions. End-of-day surveys measure social connectedness (loneliness, perceived social support, and tie strength) and mental health (positive and negative affect, depression, anxiety, and perceived stress). Statistical techniques for longitudinal data, including structural equation modeling and latent change score analysis, test the relationship between interaction characteristics and the end-of-day surveys. Insight gained by this research will inform future efforts in implementing health-related behavioral change recommendations.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was designed to understand how patterns of social interactions during the Covid-19 pandemic may have influenced psychological well-being, and which features of daily interactions contribute the most to improvements in social connectedness and mental health. We conducted analyses in two studies as part of this project.

In the first study, we collected longitudinal data from June through September 2021 from 591 respondents, as part of a nation-wide sample of US adults. Respondents completed up to eight surveys per day for three weeks. As part of each survey, they described the number and characteristics of social interactions during the past hour, and they also rated their current mood. At the end of each day, they completed an additional survey in which they reported on multiple measures of social connectedness and mental health. At the beginning of the study, respondents also completed a questionnaire measuring the recent life changes (e.g., changes in employment and family health) that had accompanied the pandemic.

There were high levels of psychiatric symptoms (anxiety and depression) reported by the sample during this pandemic period. ?Perceived social support? (i.e., perceptions that others are available to provide assistance) seemed to be an important resource for this group, as those who reported greater perceived social support at the beginning of the survey period tended to show a more rapid rate of recovery (i.e., decreases in symptoms) over the three-week follow-up. Associations between perceived social support and symptomatic recovery was not accounted for by the exchange of help per se, but rather, the mean ?responsiveness? of everyday social interactions. While these effects were observed among white participants, they were not present among non-whites. Additional research is needed to investigate social support and mental health among racial minorities.

In the same sample, daily social interactions also predicted participants? perceptions of increased social support and thriving and reduced loneliness at the end of the day. Interactions involving close relationships, conversations, and meal-sharing seem to be most important elements of interaction contributing to these effects. In terms of their effects on short-term changes in positive and negative moods, interactions that are rated as higher in social support appear to be associated with increases in positive moods and decreases in negative moods over the course of the day. Social interactions appear to reduce the negative effects of daily stressors on positive mood, and they appear to enhance the effects of daily positive events on positive mood, but they also may exacerbate the effects of daily stressors on negative mood.

In a second study, we combined large scale survey data (from almost 12 million adults collected by Carnegie Mellon University and Facebook from April to November 2020) with objective county-level measures, in order to understand some of the mechanisms through which the pandemic may be contributing to mental distress. These analyses suggested that the pandemic is increasing mental distress by increasing social isolation and worries about getting ill. There was a complex finding suggesting that county-level financial threats (e.g., unemployment rates) may have been associated with reduced mental distress, perhaps because the government expanded unemployment and other financial benefits.  However, county-level financial threats also contributed to mental distress when they led people to worry about their own household?s finances.

In summary, our findings illustrate the deleterious effects of the pandemic on mental health and point to some of the beneficial processes involving perceived social support and social interactions, at the momentary, daily, and aggregate level that appear to be associated with positive outcomes in terms of mood, mental distress, and social connection
